Day of the Dead is a celebration of life

Day of the Dead is a celebration of life in downtown Louisville

Day of the Dead is a celebration of life

Jeffrey Lee Puckett, jpuckett@courier-journal.com 11:04 a.m. EST November 5, 2014

The official poster of the 2014 Day of the Dead. (Photo: Promotional photo)

Story Highlights

  • DAY OF THE DEAD
  • WHEN: 5-10 p.m. Friday
  • WHERE: South Fourth Street, between Broadway and Muhammad Ali Boulevard
  • COST: Free
17 CONNECT 3 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Mexico's Day of the Dead, celebrated each fall, might be the most sane national holiday ever devised.

At its heart, the Day of the Dead is a celebration of love that has spread to many cultures over the last 4,000 years. It's a chance for families to remember and honor the dead in a way that doesn't preclude grief, but clearly focuses on lives well led. It's about communion with the spirits.

Over the centuries, the celebration aspect has often overtaken the holiday's humble beginnings. Honoring the dead is still a crucial component, but so are costumes, many of which are inspired by skeletons, bands, dancing and parades. Mexico City's annual celebration is wildly extravagant, drawing huge crowds.

In Louisville, that celebration happens Friday on Fourth Street between Broadway and Muhammad Ali Boulevard. A decade-long tradition, it has in recent years exploded in popularity, said Karen Welch, one of its primary organizers.

Lean more about the Day of the Dead

Last year, around 2,000 people showed up for the free event, turning the retail corridor into a mini Mexico City.

"Attendance has grown every year, but last year was it," said Welch, owner of CRAFT(s) Gallery. "People came out of the alleys for this thing. We were blown away. And there were so many over-the-top costumes. We had dogs dressed up, babies dressed up, families dressed up, senior citizens dressed up. It was fantastic."

Day of the Dead is sponsored by the South Fourth Street Retail District, the University of Louisville's Latin American and Latino Studies Program and the Louisville Downtown Partnership. It incorporates modern and traditional elements, the most important of which are temporary altars.

Altars have always been at the center of Day of the Dead. Photos, belongings and items symbolic of the deceased are placed on them in order to entice a visit from their spirit. Water and decorated skulls made with sugar are also left, because it's assumed they've made a long trip and may want some refreshment.

AROUND TOWN: 5 fun things this week

BARS & CLUBS: 5 spots for live music

A public altar will be set up Friday and people are invited to bring an object representing people or pets. Organizers and sponsors will also have altars specific to their businesses, including one Welch makes each year for Mexican painter Frida Kahlo. Altars are already on site from U of L (Nelson Mandela and Maya Angelou), radio stations (dead musicians) and Hilton Garden Inn (celebrities who have died in hotels).

"This celebration is a good, positive way to look at death," Welch said. "People have different ways of processing (death), and I think this is a good healthy way to do it for anyone, to have this kind of positive, joyful outlook.

"But people still say to me, 'Oh, it's voodoo.' No, a lot of it is based in Catholicism. It's very Christian, and we use that in kind of iconic ways. The Guadalupe is constantly showing up on altars, the Virgin Mary. The imagery is very delightful, and beautiful."

Art is a huge part of Louisville's Day of the Dead, and anywhere that skulls are prevalent you'll find Jeral Tidwell. Tidwell is Louisville's preeminent lowbrow artist, a man with an international reputation and a thriving business at www.humantree.com.

He and his wife, Sarah, will stage a show Friday night that Tidwell said will rival or exceed anything he's done on a national scale, with art ranging from $20 prints to $10,000 paintings. It marks the first major show that he and Sarah have done together.

"I've been pulling 16-hour days trying to make this the most awesome show that I've ever had, in Louisville or anywhere else," he said. "There's a piece of art in it that's literally the best piece of art I've ever made. When I made it, I was like, well, that's the end of my career. I ain't ever gonna be able to beat that."

CONCERTS: Top shows to check out

ON STAGE: 5 performances now playing

TAKE THE KIDS: 2 fun things for families

Day of the Dead is normally celebrated between Oct. 31 and Nov. 2, but Louisville's was adjusted so it could share a Republic Bank First Friday Trolley Hop. Day of the Dead art and artifacts will be for sale throughout the Fourth Street corridor. Themed art workshops will be offered, costumes are greatly encouraged, and all of the Kahlo costume wearers will be gathered for what Welch hopes is a record-setting photo.

Performers will include Appalatin, Caminos Flamenco Dancers, Arcoiris Latino Dancers and Chad Balster's Phoenix Collective, a group of fire performers. Welch said that the number of artists and businesses involved grows each year.

"People have really taken ownership of this and look forward to it," she said. "There are a lot of facets, and a new one is always showing up."

Jeffrey Lee Puckett can be reached at (502) 582-4160, jpuckett@courier-journal.com and on Twitter, @JLeePuckett.

DAY OF THE DEAD

WHEN: 5-10 p.m. Friday

WHERE: South Fourth Street, between Broadway and Muhammad Ali Boulevard

COST: Free
